author: jeanneLstarr
body: Sure.  ON. VRT.  PANW.  GLW.  AMD.  CRM.  FCX.

author: Tendiehanded
body: Corning is a good company. I only own a couple of shares but it's got a good upside after decent earnings but mixed guidance. Cheaper than COIN.

author: lattiboy
body: Wal Mart and Owens Corning had enormous jumps in options value in the last 15 minutes. Held Owens even though I’m up a ton, which is now giving me anxiety. We’ll see if it means anything, but it stuck out to me.

author: irate_wizard
body: All the telecom companies with exposure to optics are like. See GLW too, still the top manufacturer of optical fibers.

author: kekjuice
body: Me as well. I also bought corning shares and i dipped because it would always just fluctuate from 28-32 when i bought it.

author: felipunkerito
body: There's technical analysis, sentiment score and I come here so that someone does the confirmation bias. June 11 44 Call on GLW, fucking rocket fucking modafucka.

author: jay_goff
body:
Sure, try Owens-Corning circa 1950s.

Also heard. Chernobyl was nice this time of the year in the 80s.  However ya get there,  just arrive retarded 👍

author: juan62389
body: Samsung, Apple, Pfizer, US Government just a few of their customers GLW🧟‍♂️💰💰💰🤷‍♂️

author: KevinMcCallister
body: Not PPE but I've seen Corning (GLW) go up quite a bit over the past year and can't help but wonder if it's because they are making all the vaccine vials. If Covid will require annual, biennial, or some other regular booster, the demand could potentially remain high.

author: Anabaena_azollae
body:
Fair enough, I got triggered by the word "duopoly."

I think every other company I mentioned by name is publicly traded, but not necessarily on US exchanges besides as OTC ADRs. Danaher is DHR, Mettler is MTD, MilliporeSigma/Merck KGaA is MKGAF, Sartorius is SARTF (also Bio-Rad, BIO, owns about a third of Sartorius), Corning is GLW, BD is BDX, Kimberly-Clark is KMB, 3M is MMM, Repligen is RGEN, and Asahi Kasei is AHKSY.

author: StandardBorn1216
body: Bezos is Getting Out While The Gettin's Good, looks like.  Reminds me of when the '87 market crash happened some reporters went to Sam Walton down in Arkansas to ask for a story--they found him just coming in in his old beat-up pickup.  When told he had lost one billion that day, Sam replied, "Good!  I have six more left!".  Makes me wonder if I should sell some of my GLW and a few other things.  What GME is to most Redditors PTEN is to me--and I'm stayin' in!  Been makin' Serious Money in PTEN for 16 years..

author: MayoGhul
body: They have some serious lobbying power and I doubt we see federal legalization without them having a say and being at the forefront of Corning the market

author: Boston_Bruins37
body: Glw. Nice dividend that they grow, and good growth returns

author: TiChem
body: Yep I own TMO as well, we purchase from them constantly and any expansion in science spending (Biden wants to increase this) will be great. Also GLW as they make some very specific lab consumables

author: BDHurricane
body:
I'm still doing my DD on waste/ recycling but my next biggest play will likely be on vaccine waste / recycling. Those little buggers are complex.
The safe disposal of used vaccines is going to be a big challenge the next few years and I think its an untapped investment market. I havent yet looked into these but they crop up frequently as lead players - 
on site waste technologies 
stevanto 
sar metals
dwk life sciences
corning inc
apiject systems corp
sio2 materials science
agenus
amyris inc
becton dickinson

author: apecult
body: GLW got another 55million along with the 250million in 2020 from the government to help with the production of vaccine vials. GLW🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🦍

author: n00bsnoob
body: Corning glass works, you probably just typed that joke on one of their products:)

author: juan62389
body: GLW will officially be making vaccine vials for the foreseeable future🧟‍♂️💰💰💰🦍🤓🚀🚀🚀
